To communicate intention faster and more directly, <italic>Thunderclap</italic> makes several simplifications. Congressional acts combine category and year. Holding companies and corporations identified with “HC”. “MM” prefixes identify short-term liquid debt money markets. Names of people are not <italic>italicized</italic>, but <italic>firm</italic> names are and do not use definite articles. Some other institutional proper nouns are also <italic>italicized</italic>. Acronyms are generally not <italic>italicized</italic>. Descendancy is usually direct. Cousinhood is often of the first order, unless a surname, then usually implies several marriages between the surnamed families. Middle names are either maternal or maiden surnames. Some surnames have been changed for differentiation from others (e.g., Smith to Smyth).

<italic>Panics of Eur</italic><italic>asian </italic><italic>Colonization</italic>
Although banknotes in Vienna had recovered somewhat relative to silver since <italic>Imperial</italic> <italic>Austrian Bank</italic> halted redemptions during the <italic>Panic of 1848</italic>, pawn letters in the Austrian switched from trading at a premium to banknotes to a discount. Despite the shortage of silver and banknotes in the provinces, demand had grown since farms needed to pay emancipated serfs for labor. So, since the first discount branch opened in Prague in 1847, <italic>Imperial</italic> <italic>Austrian Bank</italic> followed with branches Budapest in 1851; Linz in 1852; Lemberg, Brünn, and Trieste in 1853; Olomouc, Troppau, and Kronstadt in 1854; Graz and Klagenfurt in 1855; Krakau, Ljubljana, Fiume, Debreczin, Temesvár, and Reichenberg in 1856; and, finally, Innsbruck in 1857. 
Following the <italic>Panic of 1857</italic>, British Queen Victoria began arranging marriages for her six children and later her thirty grandchildren to link the crowns of Britain, Germany, Spain, Russia, and others. Starting with her eldest, Victoria’s daughter Vicky married the heir to the Prussian throne in 1858. Although Junker Otto Bismarck became a conservative antisemitic politician in the newly created Prussian legislature of 1847, he became Prussia’s Ambassador to Russia and France by 1857 and sought a Jewish banker. Upon the recommendation of <italic>Rothschild</italic> Frankfurt, Bismarck hired Gerson Bleichröder. 
Soon after <italic>Bleichröder</italic> began stabilizing German coal and iron with cartels. As French backers abandoned the insolvent <italic>Belgium-Luxembourg</italic> RR, <italic>Hirsch</italic> saved the company in 1859 by convincing Otto Bismarck of its strategic importance. Since the Prussian government owned the Ruhr and Saar coal lands, and Bleichröder suggested to Bismarck that the Saar coal be privatized. According to reports, <italic>Rothschild</italic> Paris was interested in acquiring the Saar coal mines since 1861, but Bismarck declined. Instead, Bismarck entrusted Bleichröder to begin buying private coal roads competing with the state. From 1862, Bismarck served Prussia as PM.
America’s <italic>Civil War</italic> spurred emancipation progressed for European Jewry. From 1860 several German states made significant strides in Jewish emancipation. In 1861, Bavaria lifted trade restrictions on Jews, followed by Württemberg’s similar reforms. In 1862, Baden granted full legal equality to Jews. Saxony passed its emancipation law in 1863, followed by Frankfurt a year later. 
Unlike the forced industrialization of Saxony, Frankfurt only freed trade in 1864, approving the private joint-stock <italic>Frankfurter Vereinskasse</italic> (since <italic>Frankfurter Bank</italic> absorbed the one from) and allowing foreign banks to open branches, with the first being <italic>Darmstädter</italic>. However, industrial development faced opposition from the merchant and banking class. One of the first entrepreneurs, was Joseph Wertheim. Of unknown relation to Samson Wertheim, Joseph migrated from Hessian Rotenburg to New York and worked at <italic>Singer</italic> in 1854. Moving to Frankfurt in 1861, he married Rosalie Ballin. With the reforms of 1864, Wertheim established his own sewing machine production and soon became <italic>Singer</italic>’s main competitor.
In Russia, the movements spurred another revolt in Russian Poland. Leo Kronenberg helped form the City Delegation during the 1861 political turmoil in Warsaw, which followed Russian troops firing on demonstrators, with Russia splintering revolutionaries into religious and national emancipation, and fueling antisemitism. While Kronenberg funded Russia’s military amidst the Uprising of 1863, Wladyslaw Gutman Rawicz—whose father had transformed <italic>Zbytkower</italic> into <italic>Hirschendorf Rawicz</italic> in 1825—was hanged by Russia for his participation. As Rawicz’s cousin once removed soon married Kronenberg’s cousin, the Russian government limited the involvement of Polish Catholics in the military and civic positions in Poland and Western Russia. 
While beginning to limit freedom of the press through censorship, Russia reassessed the role of minorities, especially with the end of serfdom in the countryside. By 1864, serf-descendent <italic>Eliseev</italic> helped start and run <italic>Saint-Petersburg Private Commercial Bank</italic>, Russia’s first joint-stock bank, provided loans on government bonds, guaranteed railway loans, and other <italic>Saint-Petersburg Stock Exchange</italic> securities. While laws allowed Jewish who were First Guild merchants, university graduates, and skilled artisans to exit the <italic>Pale</italic> and live anywhere in the Empire, Jews were prohibited from acquiring, renting, or managing lands in northeast and southwest. 
Meanwhile, Britain’s Parliament spurred liberalizing corporations by limiting investor liability. Prior to 1844 and 1855, joint-stock enterprise for trading and manufacturing was prohibited by English law. The law of corporations, which granted privileges and limited liability, didn’t apply to ordinary trading ventures. The 1844 Registration Act allowed companies to be registered, providing legal recognition. The 1855 Act introduced limited liability, replacing unlimited liability for shareholders. The Acts of 1858 and 1862 enabled joint stock banking companies to be formed with limited liability. 
These Acts extended limited liability to banking companies with seven or more members, encouraging the formation of Imperial banks, often without any official connection. As lower investment risk reducing shareholder risk, a ‘Colonial bank mania’ started in 1862, increasing competition. While Parliament segregated laborers by sex before extending free incorporation with the<italic> </italic>Act of 1844, British women accounted for 31% of the labor force in 1861, the labor force participation level that would not return until 1961. 
Although Napoleon III had advocated for an act like Britain’s Act of 1862 a year earlier in France, he was unable to implement it for another five years for it.  Similarly, since French women lost the right to vote and hold political office in 1791, their commercial and administrative jobs were often limited to subordinate roles like shorthand typists, paid less than men, and frequently hired based on family connections rather than merit, including at <italic>Comptoir</italic>, <italic>Lyonnais</italic>, and BDF.
While <italic>Mobilier</italic> financed Paris gas public utilities mergers under Franco-Swiss <italic>Parent Schake</italic> into <italic>Parisienne du Gaz</italic> in 1855, French investors developed gas in Naples, which ruled by a usually friendly Bourbon regime. However, Italian unification in 1861 jeopardized that link. Within a year, <italic>Parent Schake</italic> consolidated Naples’ gas industry. 
North of there, <italic>Oppenheim</italic> Brussels cousin <italic>Schott Weill </italic>expanded from commerce in Milan to banking with <italic>Oppenheim</italic><italic> </italic>Brussels partners. In 1867, they opened <italic>Schott Weill</italic> Florence, as their sister married Enrico Guastalla, a Jewish soldier under Garibaldi and later a politician, cementing ties with Francesco Crispi as he led the branch. The same year, <italic>Rothschild</italic> hired <italic>Schott Weill</italic><italic>’</italic>s uncle to manage her Naples office since dissolving <italic>Rothschild</italic> Naples in 1863. After Jewish banker and Morpurgo in-law Ignazio Weil Weiss was ennobled in 1870 and his daughter married a noble, he became one of few nobles to invest in several banks as Catholic nobles generally did not invest.
Meanwhile, the Vatican preferred Catholic financier Andre Langrand, who soon won Church property sale contracts over Rothschild. Born in Belgium, Langrand established insurers, banks, and <italic>Mobilier</italic>-affiliated railways. Calling to unite Catholic capital, Langrand gained support from clergy and royalty. One of allies, Henri Germain, came from a wealthy Catholic Lyons family and traded silk and stock before launching <italic>Crédit Lyonnais </italic>in 1863. After the death of his first wife, Germain married the daughter of Adolphe Vuitry, former minister of Napoleon III and BDF Governor. As he moved to Paris, he was elected to Parliament and opened a <italic>Lyonnais</italic> branch in the capital at the end of the decade. 
While Germain was with involved in <italic>Mines de Montramebert</italic>, <italic>Hauts-Fourneaux de Marseille</italic>, <italic>Forges de Commentry</italic>, and <italic>Ateliers de la Buire</italic>, other founding directors included head of <italic>Forges de Terrenoire</italic> Jullien, Chair <italic>of Forges de Commentry</italic> and Firminy steel plant director Ferouillat, <italic>de la Marine</italic>’s Brôlemann, <italic>Hauts-fourneaux de Chasse</italic>’s Bouthier, Basset of <italic>Forges de Commentry</italic> and<italic> Forges de Saint-Etienne</italic>, <italic>Aciéries </italic>and Desseilligny of <italic>Creusot</italic> and <italic>Decazeville</italic>. 70 out of the 353 shareholders of the bank were Swiss Huguenots. 
By 1864, <italic>Imperial Counter for Public Works, Trade, & Industry</italic>, <italic>Rothschild</italic> Paris’ large discount and loan bank of 1856, reorged into<italic> Société Générale de</italic> <italic>Paris</italic> (“<italic>Société Générale</italic>”) with <italic>Rothschild </italic>Paris, Bischoffsheim’s in-law Joseph Cahén, <italic>Blount Laffitte</italic>, Henri Hentsch, railway, and metal cartel industries. While public works contractor <italic>Parent</italic> directed both <italic>Industriel</italic> and <italic>Société Générale</italic>, Chief of <italic>Creusot</italic> Schneider was for many years Chair of the bank and France’s first major coal and iron cartel. Within a year, France finally legalized the British practice of check payment that <italic>Thomson Bonar</italic>’s William Gladstone had lobbied for years. <italic>Lyonnais</italic> and investment bank <italic>Industriel</italic> soon led branched deposit banking. 
As Langrand imitated the French <italic>Crédit Foncier</italic> internationally, he promoted Britain’s first mortgage bank with Lord Salisbury and Drummond Wolff as promoters, <italic>International Land & Credit</italic>. While Wolff was ashamed of his Jewish heritage, his father Joseph had left his father Rabbi David Levi of Bavaria to convert and study Christianity across Europe. After securing the aid of Scottish banker Henry Drummond, to fund his missionary work in Russian Central Asia, Joseph married the grandniece of Robert Walpole, Britain’s first PM, in 1827. 
Likewise, <italic>Mobilier</italic> formed a British affiliate—<italic>International Financial Society</italic>—with the involvement of its Spanish, Dutch, and Italian affiliates, and London bankers who had previously collaborated on Pereire ventures, including Junius Morgan, <italic>Huth</italic>, <italic>Frühling </italic><italic>Göschen</italic>, and Rothschild, Speyer, and Goldsmid cousins <italic>Stern</italic> in 1863. <italic>Baring</italic> refused to join<italic>.</italic> (New Granada-focused merchant bank <italic>Frühling </italic><italic>Göschen</italic>’s George Göschen entered Parliament for the City of London in 1863 and was appointed to the Privy Council two years later.)
Amidst his entrepreneurism, Langrand founded an insurer in Vienna with Maurice Wertheim Hirsch in 1858, who him had been investing in insurers from Austria to Amsterdam. The grandson of Bavarian Court Jew Jacob Hirsch and Samson Wertheim’s descendant, Karolina, Maurice joined <italic>Bischoffsheim</italic> <italic>Goldschmidt</italic> in 1851. Only after Maurice came up with a simple solution for a complex government financing problem did Bischoffsheim consent for Maurice to marry his daughter Clara in 1855. That year, <italic>Bischoffsheim </italic>and<italic> Hirsch</italic> joined <italic>Rothschild</italic> Frankfurt, <italic>Eichthal</italic>, and Bavaria’s public <italic>State Bank</italic> to finance <italic>Bayerische </italic>RR, linking Nürnberg-Regensburg, München-Regensburg-Passau. After co-founding <italic>Bischoffsheim</italic> <italic>Cassel</italic> <italic>Hirsch</italic><italic> </italic>of London in 1857, Maurice joined his brother-in-law to start <italic>Bischoffsheim Hirsch</italic> in Brussels in 1862. 
Still, Dutch commerce lagged Antwerp and Belgian railways. In the 1840s, economic liberalism dominated Dutch policy, opposing state involvement in industry. In 1856, four proposals for a crédit mobilier type-bank—including one by <italic>Königswarter</italic> and Jewish bankers from Amsterdam—were submitted, but the government, advised by <italic>Nederlandsche Bank</italic>, rejected them. Likewise, the government held that state aid for railway construction should only be applied in the most urgent cases. 
Among the Netherlands’ first industrialists was Samuel Sarphati. Amsterdam born Sarphati wed a Mendes and his sister married a DaCosta. After starting medical oriented institutions, including <italic>Netherlands Society for the Promotion of Pharmacy</italic> in 1842 and <italic>Public Trade School</italic> in 1845, he established <italic>Society for Agriculture & Land Reclamation</italic> in 1848, <italic>Association for Popular Industry</italic> in 1852, <italic>Society for Flour & Bread Factories</italic> in 1856, and <italic>National Mortgage Bank</italic> in 1861. 
Since his brother married Matilda DaCosta—a granddaughter of Meir Pressburger and a first cousin once removed Isaac Goldsmid—Louis Pincoffs entered the Rotterdam municipal council in 1856, advanced to the Provincial States in 1858. Together with his in-law Henry Kerdijk he founded <italic>Kerdijk Pincoffs</italic>, which in 1857 took over a British firm’s assets in the Congo and opened trading posts selling fabrics, earthenware, glass, hardware, arms, and liquor, while exporting palm oil, palm kernels, ground nuts, ivory, rubber, and coffee. While fellow Rotterdam private banker <italic>Mees</italic>—started a century earlier and led by Christians descended from Emperor Charlemagne and related to the Coymans—also set up East African trade, they were not successful.
In 1861, the Netherlands passed approved a bill for state railway construction. With the construction of <italic>Nederlandsche Centraal-Spoorweg</italic>, <italic>Cahén</italic> Amsterdam’s Josef Cahén—a Mendes-in-law and brother of <italic>Bischoffsheim</italic>’s in-law Antwerp banker Joseph Cahén—soon became a board member of the in 1862. However, amidst the commodity supply crunch caused by America’s Civil War, the Netherlands ended <italic>Netherlands Trading Society</italic>’s monopoly and legalized Dutch East Indies private trade. However, demise of the Dutch cultivation system prompted a rush of entrepreneurs seeking credit, exacerbating a capital shortage and leading to a severe economic crisis in 1862. 
By 1863, the Netherlands passed the Bank Act of 1863 while confirming <italic>Nederlandsche Bank</italic>’s monopoly on banknotes. As an alternative supply source to war-torn America, the Netherlands. Since rejecting all bank proposals in 1856, the government authorized all applications in 1863. The first was Sarphati's <italic>Dutch</italic> <italic>Bank of </italic><italic>Credit & Deposit</italic>, with capital mostly from French <italic>Comptoir</italic>, including Édouard Hentsch, Louis Bischoffsheim, and Joseph Cahén. <italic>Wertheim Gomperz</italic> also gained a directorship. <italic>Comptoir</italic> hired Cahén’s nephew Hermann Wallich that year.
Meanwhile, Mennonites reinforced banking and trading kinterlinks. While his father had two Clercq grandparents, Jan Eeghen married <italic>Baring</italic> cousin Labouchere by 1850. From that year, in the Dutch Indies, entrepreneurs signed a contract with tin concessionaires on Billiton. By 1856, a Rotterdam merchant house opened a branch in Padang, followed by another in 1857, while <italic>Netherlands Trading Society</italic> and <italic>Javasche Bank</italic> opened agencies outside Java. By 1860, tin miner <italic>Billiton</italic> started in 1860.  
Entrepreneurs also founded several East Indies-focused banks. Before the Bank Act, limited partnerships did not require registration. Discounting Indies trade bills out of London for Twente textile producers since 1858, the Mennonite Blijdenstein textile banking family established <italic>Twentsche</italic><italic> </italic>in Amsterdam, a credit union that excluded Spanjaard and other Jews, in 1861. After the Bank Act, active investment spurred mixed religious institutions. 
While Rotterdam’s <italic>Ezechiels</italic>, <italic>Pincoffs</italic>, and <italic>Mees</italic> supported <italic>Rotterdamsche Bank</italic><italic> </italic>in 1863, Rotterdam businessmen and Twente producers founded <italic>Internationale Credieten</italic>. Likewise, Leo Lippmann’s brother-in-law Alex Mendel and Mennonite merchant Frans Heukelom founded <italic>Neerlandais Bank</italic>. Investors included Jews such as <italic>Lippmann Rosenthal</italic>, <italic>Bischoffsheim Hirsch</italic>, <italic>Cahén</italic>, <italic>Fould</italic>, and the Pereires, along with <italic>Crédit Mobilier</italic>, and Protestants like <italic>Bunge</italic>, <italic>Staphorst</italic>, <italic>Insinger</italic>, <italic>Goll</italic>, <italic>Wurjhain</italic>, and <italic>Eeghen</italic>. 
Within a year, <italic>Neerlandais</italic> created <italic>East Indies Trading Bank</italic>, <italic>Indies</italic> RR, and attempted to create a bank in Surinam. After being represented by <italic>Borneo Co</italic> since 1859, <italic>Chartered Bank of India, Australia & China</italic> branched to Batavia in 1863, with <italic>Hope</italic> soon becoming her in Amsterdam correspondent.
Parallel to this, <italic>Pincoffs</italic> and <italic>Mees</italic> co-founded <italic>Nederlandsch-Indische Gas</italic>, <italic>Holland-Amerika Shipping</italic>, and reorganized <italic>Kerdijk Pincoffs</italic> as a limited liability company,<italic> Afrikaansche Handelsvereeniging</italic><italic>,</italic> in 1869. After a <italic>Lissa Kann</italic> in-law married Louis Pincoffs’ niece in 1870, he became the first Jewish member of the First Chamber<italic>.</italic><italic></italic>
Meanwhile, after Galician Count Jozef Russocki joined the commission to reorg <italic>Galician Mortgage Credit Society </italic>in 1861, his cousin-in-law was Count Seweryn Dunin-Borkowski and their cousin-in-law was Count Wlodzimierz Borkowski. In 1861, the Brody Chamber of Commerce formed a committee led by Dunin-Borkowski to negotiate with <italic>Austrian</italic> RR for rights granted in the 1858 concession. In 1862, <italic>Austrian</italic> RR approved the transfer, and the Ministry of Commerce authorized Borkowski and Mayer Kallir to launch a stock subscription for <italic>Lemberg</italic><italic>-Brody</italic> RR. However, the offering raised only one-fourth of the projected cost. 
Likewise, in Romania, aristocratic politician Petre Sturdza Mavrogheni received a royal railway concession in 1861, from northern Moldova to Galatz with branches to Jassy. In early 1862, he partnered with Prince Leon Sapieha and British contractor Thomas Brassey, affiliated with <italic>Blount Laffitte</italic> since the 1840s. As Brassey sent engineers to evaluate the investment, they concluded costs were underestimated.
Along with <italic>Neerlandais</italic>, Langrand formed <italic>Bank of Land & Industry Credit</italic> to develop Austrian agriculture. Since <italic>Imperial</italic> <italic>Austrian Bank</italic> opened provincial branches, Austrian Galicia and attracted banks to extend into Bukovina, where <italic>Imperial</italic> <italic>Austrian Bank</italic> did not branch for another decade. Challenging <italic>Rothschild </italic>Vienna’s dominance in Vienna, President of the Galician Parliament, Radziwill cousin Prince Leon Sapieha, promoted concession and financing of <italic>Lemberg</italic>-<italic>Czernowitz</italic> RR to connect Bukovina to <italic>Moldovan</italic> RR at the Russian border. 
Beating rival <italic>Imperial Privileged Union Bank of Austria</italic>, which had the support of <italic>Metropolitan & Provincial Bank</italic>’s Lord Fermoy, former EIC Deputy-Chair Mangles, <italic>Overend Gurney</italic>, and <italic>Agra Masterman</italic>, Sapieha organized <italic>Anglo-Austrian Bank</italic> with <italic>Glyn</italic>, <italic>Smyth</italic> cousin Samuel Beaumont, Hungarian Count Edmond Zichy of Vienna, and Vienna’s Chamber of Commerce. Becoming Chair, Saphiea’s director was Karl Mahs Klein, who earlier married the converted noble Amalia Seligmann Hönig and ran <italic>Stiglitz</italic> Saint-Petersburg and <italic>Danube Shipping</italic>.
As  Katz-cousin Victor Offenheim—a relative of Arnstein, Herz, and, further back, Johann and Esther Liebman, Goldschmidt, Gomperz, and Schiff—established<italic> </italic><italic>Lemberg</italic>-<italic>Czernowitz</italic> RR, <italic>Anglo-Austrian Bank</italic> organized <italic>Bohemian Discount Bank</italic> in Prague along with<italic> Lower Austrian Discount </italic><italic>Bank</italic> of Vienna, which also founded <italic>Moravian Discount Bank </italic>in Brünn. A mortgage bank started in Prague in 1864 with a focus on sugar, becoming the Empire’s first agricultural credit institute.
In 1864, Sapieha and Johann Herz took over the consortium for <italic>Lemberg</italic><italic>-</italic><italic>Brody</italic><italic>-</italic><italic>Tarnopol</italic> RR. <italic>Creditanstalt</italic>, <italic>Pressburger-</italic><italic>Todesco</italic>, Count Borkowski, and other aristocrats joined competing efforts. In 1865, the Sapieha group received the contract, but financial instability drove them to return and seek an alliance with their former rivals. Likewise, Count Russocki joined the board of <italic>Galician Mortgage Credit Society</italic>.  
By then, Isaac Pereire, <italic>Sina</italic>, Lämel- and Rothschild Beyfus-in-law <italic>Haber</italic>, <italic>Mallet</italic>, <italic>Hottinguer</italic>, and other <italic>Crédit Mobilier</italic> investors founded <italic>Österreichische Boden</italic><italic>c</italic><italic>redit</italic> to acquire estates like<italic> Crédit Foncier</italic>. Within a year, the latter founded <italic>Wiener</italic> investment bank like <italic>Mobilier</italic>. Along with <italic>TURK </italic>and<italic> Anglo-Austrian</italic>, <italic>Glyn</italic>, London’s largest private bank, promoted one for Italy in 1864 and <italic>London & San Francisco Bank</italic> in 1865 with <italic>Morgan</italic>, <italic>Bischoffsheim Goldschmidt</italic>, <italic>Stern</italic>, <italic>Sulzbach</italic>, and <italic>Frühling </italic><italic>Göschen</italic>. (While the founders allowed only allowed ten investors, they later admitted <italic>Russell</italic>.) 
In 1864, <italic>Agra Masterman </italic>partnered with a <italic>Rodocanachi</italic> cousin to launch <italic>Anglo-Egyptian Bank</italic><italic> </italic>and <italic>General Credit & Finance Co</italic>, to compete with the Anglo-Greek <italic>Egyptian Bank</italic> under British laws, which were less restrictive than those in France, <italic>Anglo-Egyptian Bank</italic> relied on French capital through <italic>Crédit Agricole</italic>, <italic>Pastré</italic> of Marseilles, and Greek <italic>Sinadino</italic> in Egypt. The collapse of <italic>Agra Masterman </italic>in the <italic>Panic of 1866</italic> led <italic>Anglo-Egyptian Bank</italic> to ally with <italic>Crédit Foncier</italic>. 
The opening of the <italic>Suez Canal</italic> in 1869 spurred new financial links. <italic>Creditanstalt</italic> Alexandria transformed into <italic>Austro-Egyptian Bank</italic> in collaboration with <italic>Anglo-Austrian Bank</italic>. Likewise, <italic>Franco-Egyptian Bank</italic> in 1870, with funders including Joseph Gunzburg and Paul Haarbleicher, who had married a Rheims, related to the Fould, Aron, and Lazard families.
Meanwhile, market losses in the fall of 1864, <italic>Neerlandais</italic>’ Mendel fled to America, leaving the bank to absorb large losses and requiring s capital injections from Langrand and the foreign crédit mobilier banks. Langrand proliferated banks as he encountered difficulties. So, when <italic>Anglo-Austrian Bank</italic> began competing with him and <italic>Mobilier</italic>, Langrand cooperated with Maurice Hirsch for support. And when <italic>Bank of Land & Industry Credit </italic>faced difficulties, he organized <italic>International</italic> <italic>Mortgage</italic> and <italic>Saxon Mortgage Bank</italic> to assist it. And then <italic>General Bank for Developing Agriculture & Public Works</italic>.
<italic>Oppenheim</italic> Cologne also used the opportunity to unite Prussian, Saxon, and Polish capital.<italic> </italic>In 1864, an <italic>Oppenheim</italic> Cologne heiress married a nephew of the wife of <italic>Lippmann Rosenthal</italic>’s Leo Lippmann. And after an <italic>Oppenheim</italic> Cologne heiress married Polish Saxon banker Frankel Kaskele in 1857, <italic>Oppenheim</italic> Cologne instigated the Kaskeles to form Saxon<italic> </italic>central bank <italic>Sächsische</italic> in Dresden with investment from <italic>Rothschild</italic>, <italic>Bleichröder</italic>, and others in 1865.
By 1865, Austria faced a financial crisis with an impending deficit and weak economic conditions. To address this, the Austrian government turned to <italic>Rothschild</italic> and <italic>Baring</italic> for a loan. Negotiations were initially challenging, with the latter declining the loan but expressing willingness to cooperate if Rothschild participated. As negotiations slowly progressed, the suspension of the Austrian constitution weakened Austria’s position. Additionally, Napoleon III’s decision to authorize the subscription of bonds only in Paris hindered <italic>Rothschild</italic>’s attempt to secure advantages. 
Despite these challenges, the loan was eventually authorized, providing Austria with financial means to resist Prussian threats. So, <italic>Anglo-Austrian Bank</italic>, <italic>Rothschild</italic> Vienna, and Lämel- and Rothschild Beyfus-in-law <italic>Haber</italic> promoted an extension of <italic>Austrian</italic> RR and related rails from Galicia to Croatia and Transylvania, listing shares on the German and British exchanges, with a state profit guarantee. Against the <italic>Treaty of Chaumont</italic>, Bismarck sought to unify the German states. By 1866, Prussia defeated joint Austrian and Bavarian forces. 
Within a year, Bismarck united North German states, Frankfurt, and other principalities. As Prussian law spread, Frankfurt experienced an economic upswing, marking its transition into an industrial hub, and Jewish emancipation from the ghetto allowed nationwide freedom of movement and citizenship, creating a uniform legal framework for civil equality. This framework extended to southern states by 1871. While Bismarck switched bankers from <italic>Rothschild</italic> to Bleichröder, <italic>Prussian Bank</italic>,<italic> Frankfurter Bank</italic>, and other note-issuers continued until fusing into <italic>Reichsbank</italic> (“GRB”) in 1876.
